q: What is data exploration primarily used for?
options: Cleaning errors|Understanding patterns in data|Building final models|Deploying AI
explain: Data exploration helps understand patterns, trends, and anomalies.

q: Which plot is best to see the distribution of a single numeric variable?
explain: Histograms show frequency distribution of numeric data.

q: Which measure represents the middle value of a sorted dataset?
explain: Median is the middle value when data is ordered.

q: Which measure indicates how spread out the data is?
explain: Variance measures dispersion around the mean.

q: What does a box plot highlight well?
explain: Box plots show quartiles and potential outliers.

q: Which chart best shows relationship between two numeric variables?
explain: Scatter plots display relationships and trends between two variables.

q: What is the mode?
options: Average of data|Most frequent value|Middle value|Difference between max and min
explain: Mode is the value that appears most often.

q: Which step deals with checking missing values?
explain: During exploration, we profile missing values.

q: Which term refers to unusually high or low values?
explain: Outliers are extreme values that deviate from others.

q: What does correlation measure?
options: Causation|Similarity of categories|Linear relationship strength|Time-based change
explain: Correlation quantifies the strength of linear association.

q: Which value is sensitive to outliers?
explain: Mean can be skewed by extreme values.

q: Skewness describes which property?
explain: Skewness indicates if data is left or right skewed.

q: What is the interquartile range (IQR)?
explain: IQR is the range between the 75th and 25th percentiles.

q: Which plot is suitable for categorical data counts?
explain: Bar charts display counts for categories.

q: What should you do if many values are missing in a column?
options: Always delete the dataset|Ignore missing values|Assess impact and impute or drop|Convert to text
explain: Decide based on importance: impute or remove.

q: Data profiling means?
options: Building models|Summarizing structure and quality|Deploying apps|Encrypting data
explain: Profiling summarizes types, ranges, and completeness.

q: Which statistic shows typical central value?
explain: Mean is a common measure of central tendency.

q: A pie chart is best used for?
explain: Pie charts show proportions among categories.

q: Which technique reduces the effect of different scales?
explain: Standardization scales features to mean 0, variance 1.

q: Normalization commonly rescales values to which range?
explain: Min-max normalization maps data between 0 and 1.

q: Which step helps detect duplicate records?
explain: Exploration includes checking duplicates to ensure quality.

q: Which diagram shows minimum, Q1, median, Q3, and maximum?
explain: Box plots summarize distribution with five-number summary.

q: If correlation is close to 0, it means?
options: Strong linear relation|No linear relation|Perfect relation|Causation
explain: Near-zero correlation suggests weak/no linear relation.

q: Which approach helps understand time trends?
explain: Line charts show changes over time.

q: What does a scatter plot point represent?
options: A category|A single data record with two values|An average|A frequency bin
explain: Each point corresponds to paired values (x,y).

q: Which term refers to converting text labels into numbers?
explain: Encoding maps categories to numeric codes.

q: Which summary is NOT part of the five-number summary?
explain: Five-number summary uses min, Q1, median, Q3, max (not mean).

q: Which plot quickly shows frequency of categories like grades?
explain: Bar charts show category frequencies.

q: What is a data dictionary?
options: A list of model results|Documentation of fields and meanings|An algorithm|A chart type
explain: It describes variables, types, and allowed values.

q: What is the range of a dataset?
options: Mean value|Difference between max and min|Median value|Sum of values
explain: Range measures spread from min to max.

q: Which chart helps detect clusters and patterns?
explain: Scatter plots can reveal clusters and patterns.

q: What does missing completely at random (MCAR) imply?
options: Depends on a variable|Unrelated to any variable|Due to data entry|Caused by outliers
explain: MCAR means missingness is independent of data.

q: When exploring text data, which quick measure is useful?
explain: Word count indicates length or verbosity of text.

q: Which visual compares multiple categories over time?
options: Stacked bar chart|Pie chart|Box plot|Scatter plot
explain: Stacked bars show category parts across time.

q: Which statistic is robust to outliers?
explain: Median is less influenced by extreme values.

q: What does a heatmap commonly display in exploration?
explain: Heatmaps visualize correlations between variables.

q: What is standard deviation?
options: Square of mean|Square root of variance|Median minus mean|Maximum minus minimum
explain: It is the square root of variance, showing spread.

q: Which first step is typical in EDA?
options: Choose model|Plot graphs and compute summaries|Deploy app|Write report
explain: EDA begins with summaries and visualizations.

q: If data is right-skewed, which is true?
explain: Right skew pulls the mean to the right (larger).

q: Which chart is NOT suitable for showing proportions?
explain: Histograms show numeric distributions, not category proportions.

q: Why is EDA important before modeling?
options: It guarantees 100% accuracy|It reveals structure, issues, and insights|It replaces training|It handles deployment
explain: EDA uncovers patterns, quality issues, and guides modeling.
